refnamediv.refpurpose: map user names using an arbitrary file

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: pam_alias is a PAM module which provides a way to map user names using an arbitrary file.

The module looks up the user name (PAM_USER) in the file specified by file=filename. Every line in filename contains a pair of user names, separated by whitespace; pam_alias will map from the first user name to the second. The mapping is done by changing the PAM_USER item, which is then typically used by other PAM modules.

If a matching user name is found, PAM_IGNORE is returned; if no match could be found, the behavior depends on the nomatch option. If nomatch=fail, pam_alias will return PAM_AUTH_ERR. If nomatch=ignore (the default), pam_alias will return PAM_IGNORE as in the successful case; however, no replacement will have taken place.

If a configuration error is encountered (for example, if filename can not be opened, its access permissions seem unsafe, or if invalid arguments are passed to pam_alias), then PAM_SERVICE_ERR will be returned.
No credentials are awarded by this module.

listitem.para: File containing a pair of user names per line, separated by whitespace. The first name specifies the user name to be matched, the second name the user name will be replaced with. The file may not be world writable.
What to do if no user name could be matched. Default is ignore.

refsect1.title: MODULE TYPES PROVIDED
refsect1.para: All module types (auth, account, password and session) are provided.

refsect1.title: EXAMPLES
refsect1.para:
pam_alias was written for use in multidomain setups that intend to use PAM as authentication provider. Specifically, pam_alias is used to map ejabberd jids to local unix users for authentication.
On top of /etc/pam.d/ejabberd:
# # map specific ejabberd jids to local users # auth required pam_alias.so file=/etc/secure/jidmap
/etc/secure/jidmap:
# lines starting with hash are ignored foo@sub.example.org loclfoo
This will map an authentication request for foo@sub.example.org to the user name loclfoo, which will then in turn be used by the subsequent PAM modules.
